componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A lot of ground covered. Just a couple of other things and we kind of hit on this inventory issue quite a bit, but what is currently in your excess stock kind of lined up with where the market is? In other words, is the stock in laundry, is it at the wron
componenttext: A lot of ground covered. Just a couple of other things and we kind of hit on this inventory issue quite a bit, but what is currently in your excess stock kind of lined up with where the market is? In other words, is the stock in laundry, is it at the wrong price points, is that why it actually backed up or is kind of just more generic demand issue?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. I think it's pretty simple. Actually, it's the demand in North America was slower than we expected going into the quarter. Big part of the slowdown started by the middle of the quarter. We started making adjustments and in terms of the mix of i
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. I think it's pretty simple. Actually, it's the demand in North America was slower than we expected going into the quarter. Big part of the slowdown started by the middle of the quarter. We started making adjustments and in terms of the mix of inventory and everything like that, and again we're talking about 4 or 5 days. That's not an unmanageable amount for our kind of business.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, Roy, you went through that in pretty good detail but I was just looking back and looking at inventory to sales Q4 the last several years and it's been about 50% plus or minus, which would say, $2.4 billion is where you'd want to end the year on a
componenttext: I mean, Roy, you went through that in pretty good detail but I was just looking back and looking at inventory to sales Q4 the last several years and it's been about 50% plus or minus, which would say, $2.4 billion is where you'd want to end the year on a normalized basis and you're actually $600 above that right now.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was actually computing $2.5 billion but we're in the same relevant range.
componenttext: Yes, I was actually computing $2.5 billion but we're in the same relevant range.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you only really see a couple hundred million needing to -- so you're going to be above $2.5 billion but you wouldn't be view that as abnormal given the seasonality and product transition that you were talking about?
componenttext: But you only really see a couple hundred million needing to -- so you're going to be above $2.5 billion but you wouldn't be view that as abnormal given the seasonality and product transition that you were talking about?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think, again, I think that the point I was trying to make Jeff, is that we came into the year -- I mean, we came into the year with low inventory levels and we talked about that in the first couple of quarters. So we had the intention of building a
componenttext: No. I think, again, I think that the point I was trying to make Jeff, is that we came into the year -- I mean, we came into the year with low inventory levels and we talked about that in the first couple of quarters. So we had the intention of building a couple of hundred million dollars of inventory from where we ended the year last year. In the third quarter, that's typically a quarter if you sort of look at us year-in and year-out where we used about $100 million in terms of incremental inventory build. This year, that incremental inventory build was $300 million. And that $200 million delta was my point with respect to this excess inventory sort of traditionally where we're at the normal inventory builds and seasonality. So I'm not trying to imply that we've now lifted a new level with respect to what's normal. I'm just trying to isolate how much of this is what we intended to do, how much of it is for sort of seasonality based build which are 2 days and then this excess of 4 days that we have. We do have, as I said Jeff earlier, we do have this one day in transition but Marc and I would both tell you that's going to be with us for a while until we get through these product transitions.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tasha, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Whirlpool third quarter conference call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and CEO; Mike Todman, President of Whirlpool International; Marc Bitzer, President of Whirlpool North Amer
componenttext:
Thank you, Tasha, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Whirlpool third quarter conference call. Joining me today are Jeff Fettig, our Chairman and CEO; Mike Todman, President of Whirlpool International; Marc Bitzer, President of Whirlpool North America; and Roy Templin, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, let me remind you that, as we conduct this call, we will be making forward-looking statements to assist you in understanding Whirlpool Corp.'s future expectations. Our actual results could differ materially from these statements due to many factors discussed in our latest 10-K and 10-Q.
Turning to Slide 2, we want to remind you that today's presentation includes non-GAAP measures. We believe that these measures are important indicators of our operations, as they exclude items that may not be indicative of our core operating results.
We also think that the adjusted measures will provide you with a better baseline for understanding trends in our underlying business. Listeners are directed to the Appendix section of our presentation on Slide 28 for the reconciliation of non-GAAP items to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
Our remarks today track with the presentation available on the Investor section of our website, at whirlpoolcorp.com. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw earlier this morning, we released our third quarter financial results and you can find these results summarized on Slide 4. During the quarter, as we expected, we faced a challen
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As you saw earlier this morning, we released our third quarter financial results and you can find these results summarized on Slide 4. During the quarter, as we expected, we faced a challenging environment in some markets, which resulted in a slowing in sales growth compared to the first half of the year. We were able to quickly adapt to these economic changes due to our ongoing focus on cost reductions, productivity and our innovative new product launches. Revenues for the quarter came in at $4.5 billion, and that's as flat versus last year. On an adjusted basis, our EPS was $2.22 per share compared to $1.67 in the prior year. Our productivity results were positive during the quarter, enabled us to manage challenges related to volume in some markets, price/mix and higher material costs. On a year-to-date basis, free cash flow was flat, which was an improvement from our first half usage of $80 million. 
Now turning to Slide 5, I'd like to provide you with an update for the full year on our regional demand outlook. In the U.S., we now expect our full year demand in shipments to be up approximately 3% versus the 5% that we've discussed earlier this year. And we did see some softness in demand during the third quarter. In spite of this weakening demand environment, overall, we performed very well from a branded share perspective.
In Europe, we continued to see industry growth improved during the quarter. We've increased our full year outlook to a demand growth of 1% to 3%, as we've now seen demand growth for 3 consecutive quarters across the region.
In Latin America, we saw appliance demand rebound after some moderation in demand late in the second quarter. As you may recall, we had some significant events in Brazil during the second quarter related to the expiration of the IPI tax holiday and the effects of the World Cup. We see the underlying economic fundamentals there remain very strong and we continue to see full year growth in demand in the range of 10%.
Finally, we saw healthy growth again in Asia. Our businesses there, continue to grow at a strong double-digit rate during the quarter. We've increased our full year industry outlook for Asia to 8% to 10% for the full year.
I'll now turn to Slide 6, we you see the key drivers which are impacting our business for the year. We expect our cost reduction and productivity initiatives will continue to be the main driver behind our overall improvement as they have throughout the year. We managed our cost reduction efforts effectively and we expect to continue to benefit from these actions for the balance of this year.
As you know, we've seen foreign currency exchange become very volatile during the quarter but we've been able to continue to mitigate these risks and expect foreign currency impacts will be manageable at today's current levels. 
And finally, as we expected, we continue to see unfavorability in the area of material cost during the third quarter. For the full year, we now see material costs trending towards the lower end of the $200 million to $300 million estimate that we gave you throughout the year.
Finally, given the trends that we saw in the third quarter, we now expect price/mix to have an unfavorable impact on our full year results. And while we've had a very positive consumer receptions to our new product innovation launched during the third quarter, the overall price/mix environment was more challenging than our previous expectations particularly North America.
So looking at all these factors in total, we've been able to offset the negatives that we saw in the external environment with the internal actions that we're driving so we continue to expect to generate our adjusted earnings per share for the year in the range of $9.56 to $10.06 per share and our free cash flow guidance remains unchanged for the year which is $550 million to $650 million.
At this point in time, I'd like to turn it over to Marc Bitzer for his review of the North America operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Let me start by giving my perspective on North America's performance in the third quarter. As shown on Slide 8, we saw strong branded share growth during the quarter, driven by a consumer element innovation and an
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Let me start by giving my perspective on North America's performance in the third quarter. As shown on Slide 8, we saw strong branded share growth during the quarter, driven by a consumer element innovation and an improvement in some of the product availability issues we experienced during the second quarter. Our key new product launches are well received by consumers. And at the same time, industry volumes and the pricing environment grew more challenging than expected, and we took actions to met some aggressive competitive pricing pressure. 
On Slide 9, we detailed North America's performance in the third quarter. Net sales decreased 3% to $2.4 billion, driven by lower average sales values in the quarter. I will touch on this momentarily, but this decline is largely related to reductions in 2 major product categories. Our North America unit shipments increased approximately 1%, while U.S. industry unit shipments of major T7 appliances decreased 3% during the third quarter. And we had, as mentioned before, a strong increase in branded share during the quarter. 
Our operating margin was 4.7% compared to 5.9% in the prior year. Overall, the results were unfavorably impacted by lower price/mix and higher material cost. Favorable cost reductions and productivity initiatives partially offset the unfavorable items. 
On Slide 10, you can see some of our new products that we expect will continue to support our branded share growth. The Maytag brand Ice2O Easy Access refrigerator, which is the industry's most efficient 4-door refrigerator. It features an external counter-height refrigerator drawer that holds up to 5 bags groceries. We also launched from Whirlpool's brand most premium Front-Load Duet laundry pair. This is the industry's most resource-efficient washer and dryer. Finally, the KitchenAid brand dishwasher, featuring a modern version of the recessed handle, found on models from past decades. I would like to point out that all these new launches happen towards the end of the third quarter.
On Slide 11, the chart depicts ASV or average sales value industry trends by category. First thing you will note is that there was a generally a wide distribution on a year-over-year basis, with some categories up and others down. You will also note that the overall reduction is mainly attributable to 2 categories. We'd like to address some of our price points in these categories given the competitive environment and we saw subsequently a strong increase in our branded share performance.
It is also important to note that our new product innovation starts to provide an overall ASV lift and we continue to focus on successfully launching our new products and continuing to generate more new products in the future.
Overall, I would sum the third quarter challenging from a demand and pricing environment. We continue to address which will consumer-relevant new products to market and keeping a strong focus and cost control in productivity. 
Now, I'd like to turn over to Mike for his review of our international operations.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Let me start with an overview of our International business. Our international operating result continued to benefit from our ongoing cost reduction and productivity efforts and solid volume growth from our emerging markets. During the third
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Let me start with an overview of our International business. Our international operating result continued to benefit from our ongoing cost reduction and productivity efforts and solid volume growth from our emerging markets. During the third quarter, we experienced improved market conditions in Brazil, slight improvement in Europe while Asia unit volumes remain very strong. 
Turning to Slide 13, our European sales declined 8% year-over-year to $827 million in the quarter, with unit shipments increasing 6%. Excluding the effects of currency, sales were essentially flat compared to the prior year. The reason reported on operating profit of $26 million during the third quarter compared to an operating profit of $14 million in the previous year. The profitability improvement was driven by continued cost reduction and productivity improvements, which were partially offset by higher material costs and lower price/mix.
Slide 14 shows a summary of our Latin American third quarter results. The region reported sales of $1.1 billion, a 13% increase from the prior year period as appliance unit shipments increased 9%. Excluding the impact from currency, sales increased approximately 9%. Operating profit reached $143 million compared to $93 million reported in the prior year. The profitability improvement is primarily related to the increase in volume, cost reduction and productivity initiatives and increased monetization of certain tax credits. These favorable items were partially offset by higher material costs and lower price/mix.
Our third quarter results in the Asia region are shown on Slide 15. Net sales increased 21% during the quarter to $195 million, up from $162 million in the prior year period as unit shipments increased 18%. Excluding the impact of currency, sales increased 16%. On an adjusted basis, operating profit reached $5 million for the quarter versus the $5 million generated in the prior year period. Favorable volume growth and productivity was offset by higher material and oil-related costs.
Turning to Slide 16, you'll see just a few of our international product launches during the quarter, including the Bauknecht brand, Kosmos built-in coffee machine in Europe. The machine makes coffee and froths milk at the press of a button and can make espresso, cafÃ© latte or cappuccino. The Brastemp Ative! washing machine in Latin America. It features an additional wash basket for delicate clothes and a special option on the machine that can reduce soap stains by premixing soap and water before it comes into contact with fabrics. And the new Whirlpool brand ACE semiautomatic washing machine in India, which offers a built-in work surface and a handle and wheels for portability.
Turning to Slide 17, I would like to summarize our international outlook for the remainder of 2010. We see demand levels improve more than slightly in Europe and expect to continue to see margin expansion as a result of our ongoing productivity efforts. As we've discussed on the previous call, in Latin America, the slight negative growth rate in the second quarter recovered nicely in the third quarter despite more difficult comparisons and we expect continued growth in the region for the remainder of the year. And in Asia, we expect to continue to see positive growth through year end.
In all the international regions, we will continue to focus on productivity to offset continued cost increases. In addition, the international organization is focused on continuing to bring consumer-relevant innovation that will improve our price/mix. Our innovative new products continue to improve our price/mix in the third quarter despite the overall degradation we experienced. Going forward, we are focused on bringing more of these products to the market at a faster pace. 
Now, I'd like to turn the call over to Roy Templin for his financial review.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Beginning on Slide 19, I would like to summarize our third quarter results. For the quarter, our sales grew [ph] 1/2 of a percentage point to $4.5 billion. Appliance unit volumes increased 5% from the prior year.
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Beginning on Slide 19, I would like to summarize our third quarter results. For the quarter, our sales grew [ph] 1/2 of a percentage point to $4.5 billion. Appliance unit volumes increased 5% from the prior year. While all of our regions reported unit volume increases during the quarter, the overall increase was largely driven by higher unit volumes in our International operations.
We continue to see a significant benefit from our productivity and cost-reduction initiatives during the quarter. In addition, to this, we monetized $56 million of our BEFIEX credits compared to $8 million in the prior year. If you recall, in the prior year, we saw a significant reduction in our BEFIEX monetization due to the IPI tax reduction legislated by the Brazilian government, which expired on February 1.
Finally, these favorable effects were partially offset by lower price/mix and higher material costs. Before we take a look at the income statement in detail, there is one item I would like to highlight. During the quarter, we recorded a $93 million accrual related to Embraco settlement agreements. This resulted in an unfavorable impact of $1.20 per diluted share on our third quarter results.
Turning to the income statement on Slide 20, we reported net sales of just over $4.5 billion. Our gross margin rose 50 basis points to 14.3%, the most significant favorable impacts on our gross margin improvement related to our cost takeout and productivity actions and the higher BEFIEX credits, which were partially offset by lower price/mix and higher material cost. SG&A expense totaled $391 million, foreign currency translation accounted for approximately $5 million of the $9 million year-over-year decrease. Despite our relatively flat sales results during the quarter, we continued to generate good SG&A leverage as SG&A as a percentage of sales declined 20 basis points to 8.7% of net sales.
Restructuring expenses totaled $16 million during the quarter and were largely related to cost-reduction actions in North America. Given our year-to-date restructuring spend and our fourth quarter outlook, we now expect to record restructuring expenses in the $75 million to $100 million range during 2010. Finally, our operating margin expanded approximately 1 point from the prior year to 5.2%.
Turning to Slide 21, I wanted to briefly discuss interest and sundry expense. The $93 million of Embraco settlement expenses were recorded in this line during the third quarter. In the prior year, we recorded a $43 million expense related to the settlement agreement with the Brazilian Competition Commisison.
Turning to our tax rate, we recorded an income tax credit of $7 million during the quarter, corresponding to an effective tax benefit of approximately 9%. For the full year, we continue to expect to record an effective tax benefit of approximately 5%. Finally, on an adjusted basis, we reported diluted EPS of $2.22 per share compared with $1.67 per share in the prior year.
Moving to our free cash flow results on Slide 22. Through the first 9 months, we generated free cash use of $1 million compared with a $373 million free cash generation in the prior year. The main variance from the prior year's record 9-month results relates to higher working capital levels from the prior year end. The current year of free cash flow results include a tax refund of approximately $105 million. 
The most significant driver of our increased working capital balances relates to inventory. The higher inventory cash usage is due to a multitude of factors including product transition inventory related to some of our high-volume new product launches, a general rebuild from the low level of inventory at year end and some excess stock at the end of Q3 due primarily to slowing industry demand levels in North America.
We have specific plans in place to reduce these balances during the fourth quarter in addition to our typical seasonal drawdown. On a year-to-date basis, our capital spending has increased $39 million, largely as a result of new product launch spending in the North America region. We continue to expect full year capital spending will be between $575 million and $625 million.
Turning to Slide 23, I would like to highlight our progress in debt reduction. On a year-to-date basis, we have repaid $380 million of borrowings. While our net-debt levels increased slightly since the December 31, we expect to bring our net-debt balance below the prior year-end levels based on our full year free cash flow outlook.  
On slide 24, we summarized our net liquidity position. As you can see from this table, our net liquidity position was over $2.7 billion as of September 30. Based on the amended credit agreement that we entered in to last year, our revolving credit facility is scheduled to downsize by $522 million in December. Even with the facility step down, our cash balances and remaining $1.35 billion credit line availability provide us with significant liquidity.
On Slide 25, you can see a summary of our full year outlook. We are now expecting to report GAAP earnings per share in the range of $7.80 and $8.30 per share. On an adjusted basis, our outlook is for diluted earnings per share in the range of $9.56 to $10.06 per share. As you might expect, given the macroeconomic volatility we have been managing, there are several moving parts to our outlook. The major unfavorable driver from our previous outlook is lower full year price/mix. We now expect to see lower price/mix for the full year given some of the recent trends we experienced in the third quarter. We expect to offset lower price/mix through continued productivity and cost reduction gains, slightly lower material costs and higher BEFIEX monetization.
Turning to our cash flow outlook, we continue to protect free cash flow in the range of $550 million to $650 million. As noted earlier, we are executing several actions to reduce our overall inventory levels in a somewhat volatile demand environment. The level of volatility may impact our success in reducing overall inventory levels and therefore influence whether we hit the high or low end of our cash guidance.
At this point, I'll turn the call back over to Jeff.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Roy. Let me summarize, overall, I feel that we made strong progress this year executing against our key operational priorities. Our successful cost reduction and productivity initiatives have enabled us to significantly expand our margins during 2
componenttext:
Thanks, Roy. Let me summarize, overall, I feel that we made strong progress this year executing against our key operational priorities. Our successful cost reduction and productivity initiatives have enabled us to significantly expand our margins during 2010, despite some unfavorable trends in the macroeconomic environment and somewhat slow growth in demand in the developed markets in North America and Europe. 
From a global unit demand standpoint, our expectation for moderating unit demand is largely unfolded as we've expected, although I'd say North America demand is a bit softer and Europe is a bit better than we previously expected.
In some of our other markets, in key emerging markets such as Brazil and India, we continue to see very strong growth and are creating significant value for our company there. We remain bullish on the long-term prospects for these economies and believe that we're very well-positioned to capitalize on the economic growth potential in these markets going forward. So for the full year, our key priorities are unchanged. Our entire organization is very focused and aligned to execute against these priorities as we believe they're the keys to successfully navigating through a somewhat volatile global economic environment.
And In total, as we said through our guidance in July and I'll say and reaffirming it today, we expect to deliver a record year of operating results and value creation to our shareholders this year. 
So at this point in time, I will end and I'll open this up for questions from our callers.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The North American margin, you had shown good progress for a number of quarters in a row and you have explained or given us some color that incremental price promotion, these other factors contributed to the decline this quarter. Can you give us a sense o
componenttext: The North American margin, you had shown good progress for a number of quarters in a row and you have explained or given us some color that incremental price promotion, these other factors contributed to the decline this quarter. Can you give us a sense of your outlook and confidence in the trend as we look in 4Q and as we look into 2011? Where and why the margins go from here?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Marc Bitzer to answer that.
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Marc Bitzer to answer that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Eric, I mean obviously, we don't give a regional forecast or guidance for our fourth quarter. Let me talk about the price margin impact in the third quarter. The first one, as we expected, and with some extent talking you to already about it, and
componenttext: Yes. And Eric, I mean obviously, we don't give a regional forecast or guidance for our fourth quarter. Let me talk about the price margin impact in the third quarter. The first one, as we expected, and with some extent talking you to already about it, and we did see some degradation of the industry price/mix during the quarter, and we felt the impact as well. In particular, we observed some pretty aggressive competitive moves in 2 critical product categories already during Q2. And given our leadership position, in these categories, we decided to meet these new competitive price points. As a result of that, we saw some immediate market share gains in these distinct categories. Obviously, our job is to balance that price/mix as we did in the past going forward. What gives us confidence is some of the products which we highlight in the presentation, we just launched towards the end of the third quarter, that should give us momentum. At the same time, we do expect the promotion environment around us to sustain and we'll continue to manage the cost side very aggressively to mitigate that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, the only thing I would add is in the third quarter in North America we saw a fairly sharp change in demand which we expected to a certain degree which is higher material costs, and then we made a conscious decision to make pricing adjustments in a c
componenttext: Eric, the only thing I would add is in the third quarter in North America we saw a fairly sharp change in demand which we expected to a certain degree which is higher material costs, and then we made a conscious decision to make pricing adjustments in a couple of key product categories. So having said that, in terms of our expectations for margins in North America, this was an adjustment. We expect to improve from here. And we think that we have the tools to be able to do that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you say, and I guess I'm interested in your perspective on this Jeff, you said you've made adjustment you expect to improve from here and again, I'm not trying to pin you down to the fourth quarter margin, what I'm trying to figure out is, is thi
componenttext: And when you say, and I guess I'm interested in your perspective on this Jeff, you said you've made adjustment you expect to improve from here and again, I'm not trying to pin you down to the fourth quarter margin, what I'm trying to figure out is, is this margin going to continue to work its way towards 8%? Or are we seeing a structural change in the price points in this business that is going to flatten the rate of improvement or margin recovery in this business back towards what you've talked is a medium or long-term goal of something moving back towards whatever or 8% or 10%?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, as you said, if you go back to our third quarter last year, we made kind of 4 quarters of progressive improvement. I see this as an adjustment but not a change in direction where we want to go.
componenttext: Well, again, as you said, if you go back to our third quarter last year, we made kind of 4 quarters of progressive improvement. I see this as an adjustment but not a change in direction where we want to go.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then secondly, I guess a similar question in Latin America, excluding BEFIEX, the volumes were good, the margins flattened out and the margins in the first half had shown nice year-over-year improvement. Sequentially, x BEFIEX the mar
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then secondly, I guess a similar question in Latin America, excluding BEFIEX, the volumes were good, the margins flattened out and the margins in the first half had shown nice year-over-year improvement. Sequentially, x BEFIEX the margins in Latin America eased. Can you give a little bit of color and perspective in terms of where that goes from this point?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, it's Mike Todman. Just sequentially, there are kind of 3 things that impacted our margins in Latin America in the third quarter. The first is, there is a normal seasonality of business that happens kind of from the second quarter when you go on
componenttext: Yes, Eric, it's Mike Todman. Just sequentially, there are kind of 3 things that impacted our margins in Latin America in the third quarter. The first is, there is a normal seasonality of business that happens kind of from the second quarter when you go on to the third quarter. We didn't see it last year because of the IPI tax holiday. So that had an impact. The second is we did experience higher material and oil-related cost in the third quarter of this year than we did in the second quarter. And the third reason was that we ended the second quarter with higher inventories because if you remember, we saw a slight reduction in demand. And so we took actions to reduce production in the third quarter and that had an impact overall in the margins. I could tell you that I feel very confident that we will see margin expansion in Latin America in the fourth quarter.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A few couple of quick questions here. First off, the energy tax credits that are set to expire, I guess, at the end of this year, included in your guidance -- is there an assumption that you will hit the limit as to what you're able to recognize? Or is th
componenttext: A few couple of quick questions here. First off, the energy tax credits that are set to expire, I guess, at the end of this year, included in your guidance -- is there an assumption that you will hit the limit as to what you're able to recognize? Or is there still some wiggle room on your behalf to maximize those credits in Q4?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, this is Roy. In our guidance, we do assume that we would hit the limit by the end of the year and a lot of that, Sam, is based upon what Mark talked about which is the success rate with the new product introductions coming out in North America.
componenttext: Sam, this is Roy. In our guidance, we do assume that we would hit the limit by the end of the year and a lot of that, Sam, is based upon what Mark talked about which is the success rate with the new product introductions coming out in North America.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A related topic then, you mentioned that you want to work the inventories down a little bit sequentially. Help us on -- if you can put a little color on that in terms of where we should quantify inventories by year end?
componenttext: A related topic then, you mentioned that you want to work the inventories down a little bit sequentially. Help us on -- if you can put a little color on that in terms of where we should quantify inventories by year end?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sam, again it's Roy. Let me start and give you a little bit of perspective in terms of the inventory build and I'll talk specifically about what we're going to do and, actually, Marc may jump in here as well. If you look at year-over-year, Sam, we're
componenttext: Yes. Sam, again it's Roy. Let me start and give you a little bit of perspective in terms of the inventory build and I'll talk specifically about what we're going to do and, actually, Marc may jump in here as well. If you look at year-over-year, Sam, we're up roughly 12 days in inventories. Now, the first thing that sort of put perspective is that we came into this year with inventories much lower than where we normally are in December. If you remember, in December of 2008, we were at $2.2 billion. If you look at sort of our normal traditional exit rate in December, we're more like $2.5 billion. And we saw some impacts of that, Marc talked about that. He talked about in Latin America in terms of availability because of low inventory levels we had coming out a year. So first of all, 62 days a year ago, roughly $200 million, Sam, or 5 days of the increase from where we were at the end of year ago is basically just what we call sort of a normal build to get our inventories back to where we wanted inventories to be. So that takes you to 67 days. We've got about a day for seasonality coming out of Asia to Bali this year is in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter, and we've got about a day here in North America with respect to some of the build for the fourth quarter. So there's 2 days there that we would call seasonal build. That gets you to 69, Sam. Then we have about 4 days of excess inventory that I referenced in my script that we're going to work to get out by the end of the year and as I said, in my script Sam, that's mostly all in North America and then we've got one incremental day which is transition inventory in North America as we transition our products but Sam, I think that one day will still be there at the end of the year on a sequential perspective. So the sequential piece is really taking out this excess inventory in the action that Marc Bitzer and his team have already taken in North America.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Sam it's Marc Bitzer. Let me also allude a little bit to this one. North America has, right now, flattish to high inventory now. So it's about what we would consider optimal. And let's make it twofold. One is, yes, there's quite a bit of Q4 prebuild a
componenttext: And Sam it's Marc Bitzer. Let me also allude a little bit to this one. North America has, right now, flattish to high inventory now. So it's about what we would consider optimal. And let's make it twofold. One is, yes, there's quite a bit of Q4 prebuild around some freight commitments and the other piece is we saw the market slowdown in particular during the second part of the third quarter and obviously, it takes a little while to take that out of inventory. We have taken measures towards the end of December and particularly on October and November to run down production to what we would consider appropriate levels of inventory, which given the somewhat choppy demand environment will be slightly higher because we've got to able to respond to it to the changing demand trends. What I would like to point out is also on the energy tax credits and the inventory are 2 independent issues, okay? Actually, if you would just peel back the onion on our energy tax credit units, actually, we run lower inventories than the rest of the average, quite a bit lower. In particular in some of the new products we've closed, 5 of it when we run very low inventories. So these 2 things are fairly unrelated to each other.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think you know Sam, that we actually, we do not recognize energy tax credits based upon production under the accounting rules. You actually amortize the total expected annual demand based upon EBG. So there's not a direct-to-direct relationship
componenttext: Yes, and I think you know Sam, that we actually, we do not recognize energy tax credits based upon production under the accounting rules. You actually amortize the total expected annual demand based upon EBG. So there's not a direct-to-direct relationship between production and the amount of credits that you recognized.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. Last question, you're guiding for U.S. shipments flat to down 4%. I guess, if my math holds, in order to get to the year of 3% which suggests that you're looking at essentially similar demand patterns on a year-on-year basis in Q4 versus Q3,
componenttext: Very helpful. Last question, you're guiding for U.S. shipments flat to down 4%. I guess, if my math holds, in order to get to the year of 3% which suggests that you're looking at essentially similar demand patterns on a year-on-year basis in Q4 versus Q3, but the comparison gets much more onerous and so I guess on a 2-year stack basis, it would seem as though your expectations or that things improved meaningfully sequentially, what are you seeing that gives you the confidence to look at it in that respect?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sam, it's Marc again. I mean, I will concur with your first statement. Yes, mathematically if you take out 3%, that's where you would end up with 0 to minus 4%, minus 5%. I wouldn't conclude from this moment sequentially to have significant proof. Actuall
componenttext: Sam, it's Marc again. I mean, I will concur with your first statement. Yes, mathematically if you take out 3%, that's where you would end up with 0 to minus 4%, minus 5%. I wouldn't conclude from this moment sequentially to have significant proof. Actually, we do see and that's what we expect all from fourth quarter, a somewhat volatile market environment and that's what we see in the first couple of weeks in October and that's pretty much what we expect for Q4. But it's, obviously, this is a promotion environment where you will have quite a bit of volatility in the demand. But right now, that's why we run our forecast at 3% for full year or 0 to minus 4% on the fourth quarter.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just give us a quick update on the commodity hit that you guys have taken in the third quarter through the first 3 quarters of the year and what your new expectation is for the full year?
componenttext: Can you just give us a quick update on the commodity hit that you guys have taken in the third quarter through the first 3 quarters of the year and what your new expectation is for the full year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes Josh, this is Roy. Let me start and Jeff may wish to add a couple of comments. So the first part of your question, if you remember, in the first quarter, we actually had favorable material cost year-over-year and then in the second quarter, we have a
componenttext: Yes Josh, this is Roy. Let me start and Jeff may wish to add a couple of comments. So the first part of your question, if you remember, in the first quarter, we actually had favorable material cost year-over-year and then in the second quarter, we have a little over $50 million impact. So while we've said, and what we said in the second quarter call, and Josh, it still holds true today is, we only incurred about 15% of what we were projecting for material cost increases in the first half of the year and we have about 85% or for us, roughly $190 million of impact that will impact us in the second part of the year. For the quarter, the second part, we estimate it was right about $80 million of impact, Josh, and that was 1.8 points of hit on our gross margin. So you heard Mike and Marc and Jeff all comment on that in their scripts but it all came back to just under 2 points of negative impact on gross margins. But we're still in that. We've been guiding all year $200 million to $300 million. We're still in that range, but we would now tell you, Josh, we see it the low end of that range.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You see it at the low end. Is it right to assume that there's a slightly higher negative impact in the fourth quarter coming?
componenttext: You see it at the low end. Is it right to assume that there's a slightly higher negative impact in the fourth quarter coming?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, a small, just if you do the math that Roy gave you. But again, it's pretty much fixed at this point in time and we only got 2.5 months or a little over 2 months left and you know what's going to be and that's pretty much where it's at.
componenttext: Yes, a small, just if you do the math that Roy gave you. But again, it's pretty much fixed at this point in time and we only got 2.5 months or a little over 2 months left and you know what's going to be and that's pretty much where it's at.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess my other question is just around taxes. As we think about it and we think about 2011 versus 2010, you guys have pretty significant net operating loss carry forwards in the U.S. and also in Europe. So I would expect the tax rate in those regio
componenttext: Yes. I guess my other question is just around taxes. As we think about it and we think about 2011 versus 2010, you guys have pretty significant net operating loss carry forwards in the U.S. and also in Europe. So I would expect the tax rate in those regions to be 0. You sort of, whatever the total benefit will ultimately be for the energy tax credits in the U.S., that'll go away and then you guys are sort of looking at somewhat standard tax rates on your pretax income in Asia and Latin America. Is that the way to be thinking about your taxes for 2011 versus 2010, or should we be thinking about it some other way?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Josh, you referenced a number of variables there and you talked about the effective tax rate in cash taxes as well. But let me say it as simply as I can. We said, you typically don't get into 2011 guidance at this point in time, but I understand the reaso
componenttext: Josh, you referenced a number of variables there and you talked about the effective tax rate in cash taxes as well. But let me say it as simply as I can. We said, you typically don't get into 2011 guidance at this point in time, but I understand the reason for the question. It's an important question because we've had the energy tax credits, which have basically taken us to a negative rate. I think I said in the last call, and it's still true, that when you take the energy tax credits out and you're correct, they are currently set to expire at the end of this year. I don't know whether there'll be any action with respect to future energy tax credits or not. But you're right, they're set to expire. Once they expire, if you look at 2011 and you take that out of the picture, you go back to that rate that I've been referencing for some time, which is that high-20s percent tax rate for the global business. That rate does include the benefits of BEFIEX. I know there have been some questions whether BEFIEX was in or out of that number. So when I step back, Josh, and I look at sort of the run rate, tax rate for this enterprise, looking at our current dispersion of earnings to the second part of your question, I see it in the high 20s to 30%.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification on the inventory line. Are units up about the same as dollars? Or given the rising raw material environment, are units not up as much as dollars year-on-year?
componenttext: Just a clarification on the inventory line. Are units up about the same as dollars? Or given the rising raw material environment, are units not up as much as dollars year-on-year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Laura, let me answer it this way. If you look at -- because I referenced to Sam the days, we do have some year-over-year benefit. For Whirlpool, a day of inventory is $42 million this year. That's probably $4 million higher than it was this time a y
componenttext: Well, Laura, let me answer it this way. If you look at -- because I referenced to Sam the days, we do have some year-over-year benefit. For Whirlpool, a day of inventory is $42 million this year. That's probably $4 million higher than it was this time a year ago, so there is some benefit from a day's perspective there. But beyond that, no, I don't think there's any significant shift between units and dollars.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the slide that you had on Page 11 that talked about the average selling value focused on a few categories, what are those categories and what drove those categories down?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the slide that you had on Page 11 that talked about the average selling value focused on a few categories, what are those categories and what drove those categories down?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, it's Marc Bitzer. Obviously the reason why didn't put up the category is we didn't want to publish it. But Let me put it this way, the one on the very right side is one which has been very far, which was front loaded. The near ones are pretty much
componenttext: Laura, it's Marc Bitzer. Obviously the reason why didn't put up the category is we didn't want to publish it. But Let me put it this way, the one on the very right side is one which has been very far, which was front loaded. The near ones are pretty much our, what we call T6 or T7 categories. But it also shows you, yes, on washing machines, there's an exposed price competition out there but it's not across all T6 or T7 categories.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Was Whirlpool a leader in price competition in Q3, and is that what drove your units much better than the industry?
componenttext: Was Whirlpool a leader in price competition in Q3, and is that what drove your units much better than the industry?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that. No.
componenttext: I wouldn't say that. No.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, this is Jeff. Look, there's a couple of product categories, which certain competitors have been extremely addressing for some time. Now in the third quarter that we are in a position to launch new product innovation at both of these categories, we
componenttext: Laura, this is Jeff. Look, there's a couple of product categories, which certain competitors have been extremely addressing for some time. Now in the third quarter that we are in a position to launch new product innovation at both of these categories, we decided it was appropriate that we come back to where others were establishing market prices. So we absolutely have not been driving the leaders in driving that down. But what we found, which we knew, that at a comparable value for great products with our brands that we would have a very positive impact in share and we did. And at the same time, though, on top of that, very importantly, we're establishing new products in the marketplace, which I think, over time, will actually raise the mix back up.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from David MacGregor with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question will come from David MacGregor with Longbow Research.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a few questions for the model if I could do. The BEFIEX run rate going forward, $56 million on the quarter, should we be thinking about that as the quarterly run rate going forward? Or just help us think through that.
componenttext: Just a few questions for the model if I could do. The BEFIEX run rate going forward, $56 million on the quarter, should we be thinking about that as the quarterly run rate going forward? Or just help us think through that.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, look, I think for the year now, last call I said, we thought it'd be roughly $165 million given the run rate in the third quarter. And what we've seen in the fourth quarter, I think, it'll be more like $195 million now for the year. So if I remembe
componenttext: David, look, I think for the year now, last call I said, we thought it'd be roughly $165 million given the run rate in the third quarter. And what we've seen in the fourth quarter, I think, it'll be more like $195 million now for the year. So if I remember right, it was about $41 million and $47 million in the first 2 quarters and then $56 million this quarter and obviously, that leaves $51 million left in the fourth quarter.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So for 2011 I realize you don't want to talk a lot about '11 at this point but...
componenttext: So for 2011 I realize you don't want to talk a lot about '11 at this point but...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, David, as you know -- I mean, it depends on sales levels and it depends on the mix of products within that. So there's really not basis and we really can't give you guidance yet for...
componenttext: Well, David, as you know -- I mean, it depends on sales levels and it depends on the mix of products within that. So there's really not basis and we really can't give you guidance yet for...

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: For 2011 again, forgive me for trying to reach forward here a little bit, but pension and OPEB costs, if freights were to remain as they are now, how do those change year-over-year?
componenttext: For 2011 again, forgive me for trying to reach forward here a little bit, but pension and OPEB costs, if freights were to remain as they are now, how do those change year-over-year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, David, I don't really want to go into -- well, first of all, I can't get into 2011 pension costs because I don't know all the variables yet. And so, I wouldn't be able to do that. If you look at sort of all-up pension and OPEB cost this year,
componenttext: Well, again, David, I don't really want to go into -- well, first of all, I can't get into 2011 pension costs because I don't know all the variables yet. And so, I wouldn't be able to do that. If you look at sort of all-up pension and OPEB cost this year, it's because we have the OPEB credit in there, it's about $80 million. So if you look pension 401(k) OPEB, always a bundle, it's $80 million. Take the OPEB credits out, it's $140 million and that's basically flat lined with what it was last year. But again, depending upon where discount rates go, David, particularly in this environment, I just can't speculate on what that's going to be next year. Probably the one point I can make to you though with respect to cash and funding of pensions, as you know, we have roughly $1.3 billion unfunded status in our defined benefit plans, of course, they're frozen now. But we see the minimum funding requirements given current pension rules to be roughly $200 million in 2011 and that's an important point from a cash perspective. I just can't speculate yet David on the expense side.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess thinking about the competitive environment right now, you've got Samsung and LG that have been very aggressive in the U.S. market, we've been talking a lot on this call about the third quarter. You're certainly a formidable target for the
componenttext: And then I guess thinking about the competitive environment right now, you've got Samsung and LG that have been very aggressive in the U.S. market, we've been talking a lot on this call about the third quarter. You're certainly a formidable target for them, I mean, you're a big player in the North American market and it's easy to see why they would focus on you from a targeting standpoint. But if we talk about Latin America for a moment, you're even more a formidable presence in that market, and our sense is that LG and Samsung are kind of turning up, dialing up the gas down there as a well. Can you just talk about what you're seeing in terms of the changing competitive environment in Latin America? And sort of talk, if you can, about how that plays out in the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, it's Mike. Frankly, I don't think we're seeing today significant change in terms of competitive environment, and frankly, we feel pretty good about our position there. We continue to actually grow our market position. We feel good about the br
componenttext: Yes, David, it's Mike. Frankly, I don't think we're seeing today significant change in terms of competitive environment, and frankly, we feel pretty good about our position there. We continue to actually grow our market position. We feel good about the brands and what we're offering in that marketplace. And so, we think we're very competitive and that will continue to grow and expand our margins and our business in Latin America.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: In North American market, these 2 competitors seem to motivated more by share grabs and by profitability, is it your sense that's the same situation down there?
componenttext: In North American market, these 2 competitors seem to motivated more by share grabs and by profitability, is it your sense that's the same situation down there?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't that we can, David, speculate on other's intentions. What we do know is as part of our business, we know that we have very competitive cost structure vis-Ã -vis anyone in the world. We know our brands and the markets we serve are preferred brands
componenttext: I don't that we can, David, speculate on other's intentions. What we do know is as part of our business, we know that we have very competitive cost structure vis-Ã -vis anyone in the world. We know our brands and the markets we serve are preferred brands and what others do is up to them. But as long as we continue to offer good values in the marketplace, bring the latest innovation, continue to manage our cost structure, I feel very confident we can beat anybody in the world.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last question, just in North America, the Black Friday channel fill, it seems like the independents are going get in this year whereas they weren't last year. So it would seem that, maybe, there's more product going into the channel. I wonder if you
componenttext: Okay. Last question, just in North America, the Black Friday channel fill, it seems like the independents are going get in this year whereas they weren't last year. So it would seem that, maybe, there's more product going into the channel. I wonder if you could just talk about how the channel sale this year compares from last year?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, it's Marc Bitzer. I would, right now think from an overall perspective. We are in a promotion environment but I don't expect that site to play out very different from the previous years. So we see the typical channel moves, the typically exposure o
componenttext: David, it's Marc Bitzer. I would, right now think from an overall perspective. We are in a promotion environment but I don't expect that site to play out very different from the previous years. So we see the typical channel moves, the typically exposure of different channels with different degree. Independent retail tends to be less exposed to Black Friday by a number of retailers but they're still somewhat participating. That's what we would expect for Q4 as well.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question, you had mentioned, Roy, I guess that you're targeting some reduction in inventory about 4 days worth due to the, maybe, slightly softer-than-expected demand in North America. Depending on the success of that inventory reduction, is tha
componenttext: The first question, you had mentioned, Roy, I guess that you're targeting some reduction in inventory about 4 days worth due to the, maybe, slightly softer-than-expected demand in North America. Depending on the success of that inventory reduction, is that how we're to think about whether or not you're going to hit the, let's say, if you fully get rid of that inventory that you could hit the lower end of EPS? I know you kind of talked about cash flow as well, but from an EPS perspective, is that kind of the main driver in the remaining range from an EPS perspective?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. My comments, Michael, were more with regards to the high end or the low end of the cash guidance. But not from an EPS perspective.
componenttext: No. My comments, Michael, were more with regards to the high end or the low end of the cash guidance. But not from an EPS perspective.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, I mean, but in the guidance, if you do have that inventory reduction and your facilities are running at a lower rate, wouldn't that impact margins as well?
componenttext: So, I mean, but in the guidance, if you do have that inventory reduction and your facilities are running at a lower rate, wouldn't that impact margins as well?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if your question is, do we have some overhead in that excess inventory, the answer is, certainly we do. We think that's a few tenths of a point at the end of the third quarter. But you're correct, there is definitely overhead seen on the bala
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if your question is, do we have some overhead in that excess inventory, the answer is, certainly we do. We think that's a few tenths of a point at the end of the third quarter. But you're correct, there is definitely overhead seen on the balance sheet associated with that excess inventory.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the expectation of the impact is clearly in the guidance.
componenttext: And the expectation of the impact is clearly in the guidance.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that's built in there. Also, looking at Europe, kind of tracking at this 3% plus or minus for the full year, demand is coming a little bit better than expected. But can you talk about, obviously, at earlier points you were at 5%, 6% type of range
componenttext: Okay, so that's built in there. Also, looking at Europe, kind of tracking at this 3% plus or minus for the full year, demand is coming a little bit better than expected. But can you talk about, obviously, at earlier points you were at 5%, 6% type of range from like, let's say, '03, '04 to '07. How do you see getting back to that? I mean, is that something that given some of the improvements you can see over a 12-month basis or is it more of a 24- to 36-month basis?

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, let me just give you a perspective. I mean, as you can see, every quarter, we kind of are making progress in terms of expanding our margins in Europe. We're focused very much, and I've talked about this before, ensuring that we drive the ri
componenttext: Well, Michael, let me just give you a perspective. I mean, as you can see, every quarter, we kind of are making progress in terms of expanding our margins in Europe. We're focused very much, and I've talked about this before, ensuring that we drive the right cost productivity. So that as the volumes begin to come back, we can absolutely see that our margins are going to continue to expand at a pretty strong rate. So I'm pretty confident that we will get back to our previous operating margin levels and I can give you an exact time frame on that, but I certainly think it's well within our reach.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question, if I could. The litigation and the settlement with regards to the DOJ. One, I just want to make sure, is that kind of the end of your -- end-of-the-road in terms of this path in the U.S.? Are we completely kind of through this issue in the
componenttext: Last question, if I could. The litigation and the settlement with regards to the DOJ. One, I just want to make sure, is that kind of the end of your -- end-of-the-road in terms of this path in the U.S.? Are we completely kind of through this issue in the U.S., and if you have any update if there's any action going on from a European Union perspective.

headline: Whirlpool Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, as we've disclosed for some time now that we are cooperating with several jurisdictions. We settled the 2 we've talked about, which is in Brazil and U.S. We're still -- other jurisdictions were still, obviously, in discussions with them, co
componenttext: Well, Michael, as we've disclosed for some time now that we are cooperating with several jurisdictions. componenttextpreview: No. I think, again, I think that the point I was trying to make, Jeff, is that we came into the year -- I mean, we came into the year with low inventory levels and we talked about that in the first couple of quarters. So we had the intention of building a
componenttext: No. I think, again, I think that the point I was trying to make, Jeff, is that we came into the year -- I mean, we came into the year with low inventory levels and we talked about that in the first couple of quarters. So we had the intention of building a couple of hundred million dollars of inventory from where we ended the year last year. In the third quarter, that's typically a quarter if you sort of look at us year in and year out where we use about $100 million in terms of incremental inventory build. This year, that incremental inventory build was $300 million. And that $200 million delta was my point with respect to this excess inventory from sort of traditionally where we're at in the normal inventory builds and seasonality. So I'm not trying to imply that we've now lifted a new level with respect to what's normal. I'm just trying to isolate how much of this is what we intended to do, how much of this is for sort of seasonality based build which are 2 days and then this excess of 4 days that we have. We do have, as I said, Jeff, earlier, we do have this one day in transition but Marc and I would both tell you that's going to be with us for a while until we get through these product transitions.
